Column Comment.0: PRODUCTION ENTITY IDENTIFIER: An identifier that is unique within a specificproduction entity source and type.
Column Comment.1: PRODUCTION ENTITY SUBTYPE: the type of production entity may be equal to oneof the table names of the PDEN subtype tables, such as PDEN_WELL,PDEN_COUNTY or PDEN_FIELD. Validated by check constraint.
Column Comment.2: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.3: PRODUCT_TYPE: The product identified as a component for this table.
Column Comment.4: CASE ID: A model of proposed production for a production entity. A forecast may becomprised of one or more segments and one or more fluids or fluid ratios.
Column Comment.5: CONDITION IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the condition associated with theproduction decline analysis.
Column Comment.6: PERIOD TYPE: Indicates a period of time. Possible values are DAY, MONTH, YEAR.
Column Comment.7: PERIOD_ID: unique identifier for the period analyzed.
Column Comment.8: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.9: PRODUCTION DECLINE CURVE CONDITION CODE: a validated set of codes thatmay be associated with certain types of decline condition types. Note that only somecondition types will have codes. Others will be associated with numberic or textdescriptions only. Codes may be used to indicate whether the number of wellsincludes producing wells, injecting wells or both for example.
Column Comment.10: CONDITION DESCRIPTION: a short textual description of the condition, such as adescription of expected well conditions.
Column Comment.11: CONDITION TYPE: The type of condition that is described for the production declineanalysis, such as the number of producing oil wells, number of injection wells, servicefactors (percent of time the well is in service) etc.
Column Comment.12: CONDITION VALUE: the numeric value of a condition, such as the number ofactively producing oil wells or the service factor.
Column Comment.13: EFFECTIVE DATE: the date on which this row of data first came into effect from abusiness perspective.
Column Comment.14: EXPIRY DATE: the date on which this row of data is no longer in effect from abusiness perspective.
Column Comment.15: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.16: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.17: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.18: VOLUME DATE DESCRIPTION: Textual representation of the date of volumes forwhich this condition is valid. For example, the condition may refer to volumes for Sept1999
Column Comment.19: DATE FORMAT DESCRIPTION: Use this column to define the level of precision inthe DATE format colums, such as YYYY, or YYYQQ, or YYYYMM or YYYYMMDD
Column Comment.20: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.21: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.22: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.23: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.24: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.25: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.26: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
